title: Boundary effect - lambda and f in vacuum and glass

content.description: A light wave traveling in a vacuum has wavelength <math alttext="lambda sub V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></msub></mstyle></math> and frequency <math alttext="f sub V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></msub></math>. The wave is transmitted into a block of glass, where it has wavelength <math alttext="lambda sub G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></msub></mstyle></math> and frequency <math alttext="f sub G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></msub></math>. Which of the following correctly compares the wave’s wavelength and frequency in glass and in vacuum?

topic.text: 14.3: Boundary Behavior of Waves and Polarization

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
